children.value: We now turn our attention to arguably the most important system in all of quantum mechanics — the quantum harmonic oscillator. Here we will study the quantum mechanics of a particle whose force is of the form

children.html: F(x)=−kxF(x) = - kxF(x)=−kx

children.value: . That is, a restorative force proportional to the displacement from the origin. We know that in classical mechanics systems with such forces lead to simple harmonic motion. Our goal now is to understand the quantum mechanics of such systems.
Why is this one of the most important systems to study? The first reason is that it provides an approximation to the behaviour of

potential wells, as we outline briefly below. Second, you will see later in your degree that the quantum harmonic oscillator pops up in a huge range of situations, from describing light in quantum field theory, to describing phonons in condensed matter physics and far beyond.
In this section we will also learn a couple of general lessons about solving physics problems. First, we will use
, which is a useful way of simplifying equations, and also helps to bring out their underlying structure. We will then study the behaviour of the quantum harmonic oscillator
far from the centre of force
, to see how a particle behaves approximately when the force has become very large. Finally, instead of solving head on, we will use a bit of
and see that it can lead us to a complete solution.
Approximation of an arbitrary potential well

children.label: Approximation of an arbitrary potential well

children.value: Imagine a situation where a particle is acted on by a conservative force

children.html: F(x)F(x)F(x)
V(x)V(x)V(x)

children.value: . Let us assume that this force wants to push the particle back to a position

children.html: x0x_0x0​

children.alt: Harmonic approximation for the bottom of an arbitrary potential well. The solid curve depicts the potential energy of an arbitrary potential well. The dotted curve depicts the leading approximation to the well, which is seen to be accurate for small displacements about the bottom (i.e. for x close to x_0). This leading approximation is a harmonic oscillator, of the form V(x) \approx \frac{1}{2}kx^2.

children.value: Harmonic approximation for the bottom of an arbitrary potential well.

the form of the potential when the particle is close to the bottom of the well

children.value: , since the bottom is, by definition, a
. Thus, to leading order, the potential will be approximately

children.html: ∣V(x)≈V0+12d2Vdx2∣x0(x−x0)2.\vph V(x) \approx V_0 + \frac{1}{2} \frac{d^2V}{dx^2}\bigg|_{x_0}(x-x_0)^2.∣∣​V(x)≈V0​+21​dx2d2V​∣∣​x0​​(x−x0​)2.

children.value: We can finally make two simplifications without loss of generality: First, we can
redefine the zero of the energy scale

children.html: V0=V(x0)=0V_0 = V(x_0) = 0V0​=V(x0​)=0

children.value: . Second, we can change our co-ordinate so that the bottom of the well corresponds to

children.html: x0=0x_0 = 0x0​=0

children.value: . With these two simplications, we arrive at

children.html: V(x)≈12d2Vdx2∣0x2V(x) \approx \frac{1}{2}\frac{d^2V}{dx^2}\bigg|_{0}x^2V(x)≈21​dx2d2V​∣∣​0​x2
k=d2V(x)dx2∣0k = \frac{d^2V(x)}{dx^2}\bigg|_{0}k=dx2d2V(x)​∣∣​0​

children.value: , then we arrive precisely at the potential energy

children.html: V(x)=12kx2V(x) = \frac{1}{2}kx^2V(x)=21​kx2
F(x)=−kxF(x) = -kxF(x)=−kx
F(x)=−dV/dxF(x) = -dV/dxF(x)=−dV/dx

children.value: This shows that the harmonic oscillator is the leading-order approximation to any potential well in the vicinity of the bottom of the well. It means that if the particle is not too far from

children.html: x0=0x_0 = 0x0​=0

children.value: , then the force it experiences (and the potential energy it will have) will be essentially indistinguishable from the linear force of simple harmonic motion.

children.html: xxx

children.value: is precisely the region that is explored classically by a particle with low energy. It is thus reasonable to assume that for low energies, all systems behave roughly like the harmonic oscillator, and that this is also true in quantum mechanics. Hence, by solving the quantum mechanics of a harmonic oscillator, we hope to obtain an approximation to the quantum mechanics of any particle trapped in a potential well.
The only caveat to the above is when

children.html: d2V/dx2d^2V/dx^2d2V/dx2

children.value: vanishes. In this case, we need to go to higher-order derivatives in order to find the leading-order approximation to the potential well, and the behaviour will not be well approximated by the harmonic oscillator. The square well is precisely a potential of this kind — at the bottom of the well

children.html: dnV/dxnd^nV/dx^ndnV/dxn

children.value: . However, this indicates that there is no force on the particle whatsoever, which is a very special situation. In general, it will be the case that

children.html: d2V/dx2d^2 V/dx^2d2V/dx2

children.value: does not vanish, and that the leading-order behaviour is well approximated by the harmonic oscillator.
For the classical harmonic oscillator, the relation between the

children.html: V(x)=12Mω2x2.V(x) = \frac{1}{2} M \omega^2x^2.V(x)=21​Mω2x2.

children.alt: Harmonic oscillator potential. The potential energy of the harmonic oscillator.

children.value: The potential energy of the harmonic oscillator.
The time-independent Schrödinger equation for the quantum harmonic oscillator is

children.html: ∣Eu(x)=−ℏ22Md2udx2+12Mω2x2u(x).\vph Eu(x) = -\frac{\hbar^2}{2M} \frac{d^2u}{dx^2} + \frac{1}{2}M\omega^2 x^2 u(x).∣∣​Eu(x)=−2Mℏ2​dx2d2u​+21​Mω2x2u(x).

children.value: There are a lot of constants floating around in this equation, which can easily get confused, and to some extent obscure the form of the equation. A general method to deal with this is to
, which generally help to 'clean-up' the equation.
We would therefore like to find a new co-ordinate

children.html: yyy

children.value: , that is dimensionless. In order to do so, we need to find a combination of physical quantities that together have the units of length, which we will call

children.html: aaa

children.value: . If we can do so, then

children.html: aaa

children.value: for the system, and we can measure the physical distance

children.html: xxx

children.value: in multiples of this length scale

children.html: aaa

&\text{mass of the particle}: M &&[M] = \mathsf{M},\\
&\text{angular frequency}: \omega && [\omega] = \mathsf{T}^{-1},\\
&\text{Reduced Planck constant}: \hbar && [\hbar] = \mathsf{M}\mathsf{L}^2\mathsf{T}^{-1}.

a = \sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{M\omega}} \,\text{  has the units of length, i.e. } [a] = \mathsf{L}.

Behaviour far from the force centre

children.label: Behaviour far from the force centre

children.value: The time-independent Schrödinger equation for the harmonic oscillator potential is not as straightforward to solve as in the previous examples. Whereas for the finite square well solutions in the three regions could be readily written down, we are going to have to work a little harder to get to a position where we can find solutions now.
In order to make progress, the first step we can take is to
try and find a solution which is valid for large values of

children.html: yyy

children.value: . That is, we are going to try and find the form of the energy eigenstates
far from the bottom of the well
. Classically, if the total energy of the particle is fixed at

children.html: EEE

children.value: , then there is a maximum distance that the particle can be from the origin: It can only make it to the point where all of its energy is potential energy, and therefore its kinetic energy becomes zero. Such as points are known as the
We saw in the previous section that in quantum mechanics particles can
into this forbidden region. Therefore, if we go far enough away from the centre of force for a fixed energy

children.html: EEE

children.value: , then we expect that the wavefunction should decay towards zero, just like the decay in the forbidden region of the finite square well.

children.html: y≫1y \gg 1y≫1

children.value: form of the time-independent Schrödinger equation is

children.label: e-TISE-large-y
children.html: d2udy2=y2u(y).\frac{d^2u}{dy^2} = y^2 u(y).dy2d2u​=y2u(y).
E\mathcal{E}E
y2y^2y2

u(y)u(y)u(y)

e−y2e^{-y^2}e−y2

children.value: . Let us tentatively proceed, and calculate the derivatives:

children.html: ddyey2=2yey2,ddye−y2=−2yey2,d2dy2ey2=2ey2+4y2ey2,d2dy2e−y2=−2e−y2+4y2e−y2.\begin{align*} \frac{d}{dy} e^{y^2} &= 2y e^{y^2},& \frac{d}{dy} e^{- y^2} &= - 2y e^{ y^2},\nonumber \\ \frac{d^2}{dy^2} e^{y^2} &= 2e^{y^2} + 4y^2 e^{y^2},& \frac{d^2}{dy^2} e^{- y^2} &= - 2e^{- y^2} + 4y^2 e^{- y^2}. \end{align*}dyd​ey2dy2d2​ey2​=2yey2,=2ey2+4y2ey2,​dyd​e−y2dy2d2​e−y2​=−2yey2,=−2e−y2+4y2e−y2.​

children.value: Remember that we are interested in solutions

children.html: yyy

children.value: . Therefore, just as we approximated the time-independent Schrödinger equation, we should also approximate the second derivatives of

children.html: ey2e^{y^2}ey2
e−y2e^{-y^2}e−y2

children.html: d2dy2ey2≈4y2ey2,d2dy2e−y2≈4y2e−y2.\begin{align*} \frac{d^2}{dy^2} e^{y^2} &\approx 4y^2 e^{y^2},& \frac{d^2}{dy^2} e^{- y^2} &\approx 4y^2 e^{- y^2}. \end{align*}dy2d2​ey2​≈4y2ey2,​dy2d2​e−y2​≈4y2e−y2.​

children.value: We are very close to obtaining what we want: for this to be an approximate solution, we need that

children.html: d2udy2≈y2u(y)\frac{d^2u}{dy^2} \approx y^2 u(y)dy2d2u​≈y2u(y)

children.value: , however what we have obtained is

children.value: . We can however easily take care of this unwanted factor of 4, by considering instead

children.html: e12y2e^{\frac{1}{2}y^2}e21​y2
e−12y2e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}e−21​y2

∣d2dy2e12y2≈y2e12y2,d2dy2e−12y2≈y2e−12y2,\begin{align*} \vph \frac{d^2}{dy^2}e^{ \frac{1}{2}y^2} &\approx y^2 e^{\frac{1}{2}y^2},& \frac{d^2}{dy^2}e^{- \frac{1}{2}y^2} &\approx y^2 e^{- \frac{1}{2}y^2}, \end{align*}∣∣​dy2d2​e21​y2​≈y2e21​y2,​dy2d2​e−21​y2​≈y2e−21​y2,​

e−12y2e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}e−21​y2

e12y2e^{\frac{1}{2}y^2}e21​y2

children.html: yyy
∣u(y)=Ae−12y2.\vph u(y) = Ae^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}.∣∣​u(y)=Ae−21​y2.

children.value: -type decay. Whereas for the infinite square well, where the potential energy was constant and equal to

children.html: V0V_0V0​

children.value: outside the well, and where the wavefunctions of the energy eigenstates decayed exponentially as

children.html: e−ζxe^{-\zeta x}e−ζx

children.value: , now for the harmonic oscillator, where the potential energy increases as we move further away from the origin, the decay is even faster, now like

children.html: e−12y2e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}e−21​y2

children.value: What have we learnt: We now know that no matter the energy

children.html: EEE

children.value: , and no matter the form of the wavefunction close to the origin, for large values of

children.html: yyy

children.value: , the wavefunction must be like a Gaussian function. This means that we are going to search for wavefunctions of the form

children.label: e-QHO-form
children.html: u(y)=v(y)e−12y2,u(y) = v(y)e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2},u(y)=v(y)e−21​y2,
v(y)v(y)v(y)

children.value: is some function which we don't know much about. All we know is that for large values of

children.html: yyy

children.value: we want it not to vary quickly compared to

children.html: e−12y2e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}e−21​y2
u(x)u(x)u(x)

children.value: After solving the infinite square well, we covered some of the general properties of energy eigenstates in
. One of these properties was that the
number of nodes increases as the energy increases
the ground state wavefunction has no nodes
Although in the above we were only looking for the form of the wavefunction at large

children.html: yyy

children.value: , since it has no nodes, it is advantageous to check whether it might in fact solve the time-independent Schrödinger equation

children.html: yyy
yyy
u(y)=Ae−12y2u(y) = Ae^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}u(y)=Ae−21​y2
∣d2udy2=(y2−1)u(y),\vph \frac{d^2u}{dy^2} = (y^2 - 1)u(y),∣∣​dy2d2u​=(y2−1)u(y),

children.value: and so it indeed solves the time-independent Schrödinger equation

children.html: E=1.\mathcal{E} = 1.E=1.

children.value: Since this is a solution, and since it has no nodes, we know immediately that
we have just found the ground-state of the quantum harmonic oscillator
. If we go back to the physical co-ordinate

children.html: x=ayx = a yx=ay
E=ℏωE/2E = \hbar \omega \mathcal{E}/2E=ℏωE/2

children.value: , we see that the ground state wavefunction, which we will denote by

children.html: u0(x)u_0(x)u0​(x)
u0(x)=Ae−x2/2a2=Ae−Mωx2/2ℏ,u_0(x) = Ae^{-x^2/2a^2} = A e^{-M\omega x^2/2\hbar},u0​(x)=Ae−x2/2a2=Ae−Mωx2/2ℏ,
E0=12ℏω.E_0 = \frac{1}{2}\hbar\omega.E0​=21​ℏω.

children.value: Somewhat confusingly, for the harmonic oscillator we are going to count the energy levels starting from

children.html: n=0n = 0n=0
n=1n = 1n=1

children.value: . I am not making this choice in order to confuse you — I am making this choice since it is in line with all of the major textbooks, just as all of the major textbooks take

children.html: n=1n = 1n=1

children.value: for the ground state of the infinite and finite square wells. I can only apologise for this strange inconsistency, which is used solely so that the formulas in each case are `nice'.

children.html: AAA

children.value: is the normalisation constant, fixed as always by requiring that the total probability to find the particle somewhere is one. In the problem sheet you will show that the normalised wavefunction is

children.html: u0(x)=(1aπ)1/2e−x2/2a2.u_0(x) = \left(\frac{1}{a\sqrt{\pi}}\right)^{1/2} e^{-x^2/2a^2}.u0​(x)=(aπ​1​)1/2e−x2/2a2.

children.value: We just saw that the Gaussian solves the time-independent Schrödinger equation, and was a good
for a solution. Looking at the form
, we see that the Gaussian corresponds to

children.html: v(y)=1v(y) = 1v(y)=1

children.value: , i.e. the constant function. This is arguably the
function we could have thought of for

children.html: v(y)v(y)v(y)

children.value: We are therefore going to try and make further progress by asking ourself what is the

children.html: v(y)v(y)v(y)

children.value: . Before doing so, we are going to recall one further general property of energy eigenstates that we saw in
: The wavefunctions of the energy eigenstates are
alternatively odd and even about the centre of the well whenever the potential is symmetric
. In our case, the centre of the well is at

children.html: x=0x = 0x=0

children.value: , and indeed it is symmetric about the line

children.html: x=0x = 0x=0
u0(x)u_0(x)u0​(x)

children.value: is an even function (around the centre), as expected, and so for the first excited state we are now looking to form an
If we remember that the product of an odd function and an even function is odd, this shows that we are looking for

children.html: v(y)v(y)v(y)

children.value: that we can multiple the Gaussian by, in order to create an overall odd wavefunction

children.html: u(y)=v(y)e−12y2u(y) = v(y)e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}u(y)=v(y)e−21​y2

children.value: . The simplest choice we can take is

children.html: v(y)=Ayv(y) = Ayv(y)=Ay

children.value: . Let us see if this could indeed form a solution:

\frac{d}{dy}\left( Ay e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= Ae^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} - Ay^2 e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}, \\
\frac{d^2}{dy^2}\left( Ay e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= -Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} -2Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} + Ay^3 e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}, \nonumber \\
&= (y^2 - 3)Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}.
children.html: ddy(Aye−12y2)=Ae−12y2−Ay2e−12y2,d2dy2(Aye−12y2)=−Aye−12y2−2Aye−12y2+Ay3e−12y2,=(y2−3)Aye−12y2.\begin{align*} \frac{d}{dy}\left( Ay e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= Ae^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} - Ay^2 e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}, \\ \frac{d^2}{dy^2}\left( Ay e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= -Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} -2Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} + Ay^3 e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}, \nonumber \\ &= (y^2 - 3)Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}. \end{align*}dyd​(Aye−21​y2)dy2d2​(Aye−21​y2)​=Ae−21​y2−Ay2e−21​y2,=−Aye−21​y2−2Aye−21​y2+Ay3e−21​y2,=(y2−3)Aye−21​y2.​

children.value: Looking at the time-independent Schrödinger equation
, we see that we have again obtained a solution, now with

children.html: E=3\mathcal{E} = 3E=3

children.value: . Moreover, this function has exactly one node at

children.html: y=0y = 0y=0

children.value: must be the first excited state

children.value: ), which you will do as an exercise in the problem sheet, and expressed in terms of the physical co-ordinate

children.value: , we have just shown that the first excited state of the harmonic oscillator is

E1=32ℏω.E_1 = \frac{3}{2}\hbar \omega.E1​=23​ℏω.

children.value: We will consider one more case explicitly, before drawing some general conclusions. Let us now see if we can find the second excited state. Just as previously, we would like to make an educated guess for a function

children.html: v(y)v(y)v(y)

children.value: . We now need this to be an

children.html: u(y)=v(y)e−12y2u(y) = v(y)e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}u(y)=v(y)e−21​y2

children.value: is even. We also need it to have precisely two nodes to be the second excited state.
In order to be even, and have only two nodes, a guess at a function would be

children.html: v(y)=A(y−b)(y+b),=A(y2−b2),\begin{align*} v(y) &= A(y-b)(y+b),\nonumber \\ &= A(y^2 - b^2), \end{align*}v(y)​=A(y−b)(y+b),=A(y2−b2),​
AAA
bbb

children.value: are unknown constants. This function has nodes at

children.html: y=by = by=b
y=−by = -by=−b

children.value: , and is even. Let us see if this may also give us a solution:

\frac{d}{dy}\left( A(y^2-b^2)e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= 2Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} - Ay(y^2 - b^2) e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}, \nonumber \\
&= A\left[(2+b^2)y -y^3\right]e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}\\
\frac{d^2}{dy^2}\left( A(y^2-b^2) e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= A\left[(2+b^2) -3y^2\right]e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} -A\left[(2+b^2)y -y^3\right]ye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}
\nonumber \\
&= A\left[(2+b^2) -(5+b^2)y^2 + y^4\right]e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}.
children.html: ddy(A(y2−b2)e−12y2)=2Aye−12y2−Ay(y2−b2)e−12y2,=A[(2+b2)y−y3]e−12y2d2dy2(A(y2−b2)e−12y2)=A[(2+b2)−3y2]e−12y2−A[(2+b2)y−y3]ye−12y2=A[(2+b2)−(5+b2)y2+y4]e−12y2.\begin{align*} \frac{d}{dy}\left( A(y^2-b^2)e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= 2Aye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} - Ay(y^2 - b^2) e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}, \nonumber \\ &= A\left[(2+b^2)y -y^3\right]e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}\\ \frac{d^2}{dy^2}\left( A(y^2-b^2) e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \right) &= A\left[(2+b^2) -3y^2\right]e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} -A\left[(2+b^2)y -y^3\right]ye^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2} \nonumber \\ &= A\left[(2+b^2) -(5+b^2)y^2 + y^4\right]e^{-\frac{1}{2}y^2}. \end{align*}dyd​(A(y2−b2)e−21​y2)dy2d2​(A(y2−b2)e−21​y2)​=2Aye−21​y2−Ay(y2−b2)e−21​y2,=A[(2+b2)y−y3]e−21​y2=A[(2+b2)−3y2]e−21​y2−A[(2+b2)y−y3]ye−21​y2=A[(2+b2)−(5+b2)y2+y4]e−21​y2.​

children.value: . Therefore, cancelling these terms on both sides, we need to try and see if we can solve the equation

children.html: (2+b2)−(5+b2)y2+y4=(y2−E)(y2−b2)(2+b^2) -(5+b^2)y^2 + y^4 = (y^2 - \mathcal{E})(y^2 - b^2)(2+b2)−(5+b2)y2+y4=(y2−E)(y2−b2)

children.value: The second equation shows immediately that

children.html: E=5,\mathcal{E} = 5,E=5,

children.html: b2=12. b^2 = \frac{1}{2}. b2=21​.

children.value: Therefore, once again we have found a solution to the time-independent Schrödinger equation. This solution has 2 nodes, and thus corresponds to the second excited state (third energy level). After normalising the wavefunction, and writing it in terms of the physical co-ordinate, the second excited state is

children.html: u2(x)=(2aπ)1/2(x2a2−12)e−x2/2a2,u_2(x) = \left(\frac{2}{a\sqrt{\pi}}\right)^{1/2}\left(\frac{x^2}{a^2} - \frac{1}{2}\right)e^{-x^2/2a^2},u2​(x)=(aπ​2​)1/2(a2x2​−21​)e−x2/2a2,
E2=52ℏω.E_2 = \frac{5}{2}\hbar \omega.E2​=25​ℏω.

children.value: The procedure for the second excited state was a little more involved than for the first excited state, since now we had an unknown parameter

children.html: bbb

children.value: that we needed to find. Nevertheless, we saw that we were able to do so, and find a solution.
As a final exercise, in Problem Sheet 5 you will find

children.html: u3(x)u_3(x)u3​(x)

children.value: , the third excited state, which will follow the same procedure as for the second excited state. In particular, you will show that a sensible guess is

children.value: The above construction can be carried on indefinitely, and in fact leads to
all energy eigenstates of the quantum harmonic oscillator
. The wavefunctions of all energy eigenstates take the form

children.value: These polynomials are known as the

and were in fact discovered long before quantum mechanics. You can find a complete treatment of Hermite polynomials in almost all textbooks on quantum mechanics, and in almost all textbooks on mathematical methods for physicists. As far as this course is concerned, it is useful for you to know that these polynomials have a name, so that you recognise them when you see them in other contexts, however we will not delve further into their properties.
we list the first few Hermite polynomials for reference, and the associated wavefunctions.
Hermite polynomials and normalised energy eigenstates of the harmonic oscillator
. We give here the first 4 Hermite polynomials, and the corresponding normalised wavefunctions of the energy eigenstates of the quantum harmonic oscillator.

The energy levels of the quantum harmonic oscillator are

children.html: En=(n+12)ℏω.E_n = \left(n + \tfrac{1}{2}\right)\hbar \omega.En​=(n+21​)ℏω.

children.value: That is, the ground state energy is

children.html: E0=12ℏωE_0 = \tfrac{1}{2}\hbar \omegaE0​=21​ℏω

children.value: , which we encountered for the infinite square well in
. As in all cases, it arises due to the uncertainty principle, since the particle cannot simultaneously be stationary and at the bottom of the well.
Interestingly, we see that the energy levels of the quantum harmonic oscillator are
than the energy levels of the infinite and finite square well. For the infinite square well we saw that the energy levels are proportional to

children.html: n2n^2n2

children.value: , and for the finite square well we saw that this behaviour is basically unchanged towards the bottom of the well. This means that
the spacing between energy levels increases with energy
